Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Medium: Collaborative Research: Novel Computational Techniques for Cardiovascular Risk Stratification

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project assesses patient cardiovascular risk and matches patients to the treatments most likely to be effective. The project addresses this problem through sophisticated computational methods that identify new markers of disease, improve the ability to measure both new and existing markers, and construct personalized models that can provide highly accurate assessments of individual risk. The core focus of the research addresses the poor performance of existing tools for cardiovascular decision support through advanced methods at the intersection of machine learning, data mining, signal processing, and applied algorithms; with the research guided by knowledge of cardiac pathophysiology.

This project impacts patient care for a disease that causes roughly one death every 38 seconds in the United States and imposes a burden of over half a trillion dollars in the U. S. each year. More generally, many of the ideas explored here (e.g., personalization of risk models) extends to a wide variety of other disorders in a straightforward manner and leads to wide improvements in outcomes while controlling costs. The research also strengthens interdisciplinary research in EECs and medicine throughout the computer science research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cardiac disease is the leading cause of death around the world; with ischemic heart disease alone claiming 7 million lives in 2011. This burden can be attributed, in part, to: (1) the absence of biomarkers that can reliably prognosticate patients with cardiovascular disease; and (2) the absence of models that can factor in information across multiple biomarkers and other healthcare-related data to reliably evaluate future cardiovascular health.

This project enabled improvements in both biomarkers and models for prognosticating patients with cardiovascular disease. In one study reported in the Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Knowledge Discovery and DataMining, the project team demonstrated the ability to measure (in a computationally-efficient manner) a novel biomarker that measures subtle variations in long-term electrocardiographic (ECG or EKG) data that are usually overlooked as noise but provide a clinically useful assessment of the health of heart muscles. In two other studies (reported in the Proceedings of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence Conference andScience Translational Medicine) the study team also demonstrated improvements in the training of models that can predict cardiovascular disease and other clinical outcomes through improvements in the ability to deal with missingdata and outcomes with low prevalence. In an additional study (presented at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association) the team further established the clinical utility of a model to predict atrial fibrillation following cardiothoracic surgery. Finally, in yet another study (published in Machine Learning) the study team extended their focus on cardiovascular disease to showcase how more advanced analytics can be leveraged to improve modeling of clinical outcomes by modeling both inter-patient and intra-patient variations in these outcomes.

Beyond these studies advancing the discipline of computational medicine (and computer science more broadly) and the application domain of cardiovascular medicine, the support provided by this project was used to train undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Michigan. The research and results from this project also acted as an example of how STEM education can positively impact the human condition; as a means to attract K-12 students to STEM careers.
